ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

OPERATIONAL READINESS OF RESERVE UNITS


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for

Column: 1346

Defence, as more than two-thirds of our combat forces are in the Reserve, whether his Ministry is satisfied with the operational readiness of the reserve units.

Column: 1347



    The Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, two factors will determine how well reserve units perform in war. Firstly, the thorough preparation of men and materials and, secondly, their motivation on the battlefield.

    In peace time, Mindef makes sure that people and equipment are available, that units and individuals are well trained, and, that the mobilization system is reliable.

    Reserve units are already performing limited operational duties. Units on in-camp training are rostered with active units to be on standby. They are fully equipped and armed, ready to be deployed at a moment's notice. Every so often, they are activated without warning to test their responsiveness.

    Our reserve units are fully manned. Each reserve unit has complete emergency stores of weapons, ammunition, vehicles and other equipment. Exacting exercises during in-camp training keep reservists combat-fit. Using couriers to reach the troops in Silent Mobilization, they can return, pick up their stores, and be ready for action in less than 30 hours. We have achieved 90% success in practice mobilizations. From this year, the SAF will be conducting Open Mobilization exercises. Response will be even faster.

    On the basis of their performance in peace time, Mindef is confident that our reserve units are operationally ready. But what about their likely motivation on the battlefield? It is the one critical factor that has not been tested. If the spirit of our reservists should falter in war, then all our expenditures and preparations would come to nought. But if they respond, as Mindef believes they will, they will be equal to their responsibilities. When our reserve units combine their training and equipment with high motivation, they will be more than a match for any foe.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether exercises have been conducted regularly to test the operational readiness of the units, how often are they conducted and, if they have been conducted, how effective they have been?

Column: 1348



     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I explained, we do two kinds of exercises. One is sudden activation exercises for units which are on standby. That means, they must load up, go out, do an exercise, conduct an operation and demonstrate their fitness. The second kind of exercise which we do is a mobilization exercise, where we press the button, call people back from their civilian careers, and they have to come back to camp and get equipped and get ready to fight, within about a day. We do both, regularly, and we are quite satisfied with the results.

     Dr Dixie Tan (Ulu Pandan): Sir, would the Minister of State agree that the speed of mobilization and the willingness of mobilization would depend a lot on public opinion and public support for this procedure? And what Mindef has done about it?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Ulu Pandan has brought up a very important point, and that is, how well the reservists respond, not only the speed of mobilization but how well they perform in general. It depends to a very great extent on how well we support them, how well the public supports them.

    As I informed the House last week, 96% of the public support the idea of national service, although some of them are still not very clear about the role of reservists as front-line fighting soldiers. But we have made progress and, in this process of making progress, opinion leaders have a critical role to play. And even when we talk about opinion leaders, we have taken steps forward. I refer to sentiments within this House concerning national service, concerning national security, concerning the defence of our Republic. If we make a comparison between the sentiments in this House now and the sentiments here perhaps about a year or two ago, significant progress has been made. This year, the Defence budget was discussed with nobody disagreeing with the fundamentals of defence. None of the PAP Members, of course, and none of the Opposition Members. It is an important step forward which we should note, with happiness and with further anticipation,

Column: 1349

that more progress will be made in time to come.

    The Member for Potong Pasir has said quite clearly in his first address here that he supports the idea of a strong defence within the limits of our affordability and, if need be, he will sacrifice himself for the defence of the nation. That is entirely correct and it is a sentiment which we would like every Singaporean to have. It is a pity that the Member was absent during the Committee of Supply. So it was not possible for us to have the benefit of his views and advice on how we can better improve our national defence preparedness, but I am sure there will be many opportunities for more positive contributions later on.

    Although the Opposition Member for Anson spoke up during the Committee of Supply on Defence matters, it is worthy to note that the fundamentals were unchallenged and were presumed to be correct, that we have to spend a reasonable sum, that we must be prepared, and that we must be ready even though we do not have any enemies today. This is a very significant development which should not pass unnoticed and which, in fact, should be applauded. Such progress cannot fail to have a good effect on the reservists' morale and performance in the SAF.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): In view of the Total Defence concept, will the Ministry consider coordinating the mobilization of not only the reserve units but also the civil defence units?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Yes, in answer to the Member for Serangoon Gardens, we will indeed consider that. We have practised mobilization of reservists. We shall be practising mobilization of civil potential of equipment, and the next step would be to practise both of them together.

HDB HOUSING ESTATES
(Measures to eradicate problem of rusty water)


    2. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for National Development (a) what measures are being taken by the Housing and Development Board to solve the problem of rusty water in existing housing estates; (b) whether HDB has a comprehensive plan to tackle and eradicate this problem; and (c) what measures HDB will take to ensure that the problem will not happen in new housing estates.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, rusty water is normally caused by the corrosion of galvanized steel downfeed pipes, The HDB currently has a programme to replace the pipes of apartment blocks receiving water from reservoirs with high chloride content. The new pipes will be made of UPVC or other non-corrodible materials. Pipes of apartment blocks receiving water from reservoirs without a high chloride content will also be examined to see whether they need to be replaced. Since 1982, the HDB has been using non-corrodible pipes in its new apartment blocks.

    The HDB also has a regular programme of flushing, cleaning and repainting its water tanks. For a longer term solution to the rust problem, the HDB is studying the use of reinforced concrete and fibre-glass polyester tanks instead of steel tanks.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Kaki Bukit): Sir, the Hon. Minister mentioned in the House last week that the HDB will draw up a schedule of programme to combat the rusty water problem existing in housing estates. May we know when will this schedule of programme be made known to the public?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in about three months' time the Area Offices should be able to draw up the plan.

PROPERTY TAX
(Reassessment)


    4. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance, Minister for Education and Minister for Health how often and on what basis the Ministry of Finance re-assesses the annual value of private properties for purposes of property tax; and, in the light of the substantial drop in the value of property and rentals, whether the Ministry intends to review property tax assessments.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, property tax is payable at 23% of the annual value. Annual value is the estimated rent at which the property can be let in a year: A property is reassessed when there is sufficient evidence to show that its existing annual value is different from the current fair market value. Because of the large number of private

Column: 1352

properties, reassessment is carried out in phases, district by district, with priority given to areas which need more immediate attention.

    Consideration is given to current conditions in the property market. Any property owner who is dissatisfied with the reassessment can protest to the Property Tax Department or lodge an appeal against the reassessment with the Valuation Review Board.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister what is the sufficient evidence that he says that the Comptroller of Property Tax requires before he takes steps to amend the annual value?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, the sufficient evidence is that which is deemed sufficient by the Comptroller of Property Tax.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister not know what this is? Would the Minister assure this House that the Comptroller of Property Tax will take note of the substantial reductions in the rentals of properties, particularly in the Central Business area?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, yes.

TOA PAYOH HOSPITAL/TAN TOCK SENG HOSPITAL
(Redevelopment)


    5. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance, Minister for Health and Minister for Education, in view of the increasing population in Ang Mo Kio, Yishun and Bishan Housing Estates, whether the Ministry of Health has any plans to redevelop or expand the Toa Payoh and Tan Tock Seng Hospitals to cope with the rising demand for medical care; and, if not, whether the Ministry will consider building a community hospital in each of these housing estates.

    The Minister of State for Health and Foreign Affairs (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong) (for the Minister for Finance, Minister for Health and Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

Column: 1353



    The answer is yes. The Ministry plans to redevelop both the Toa Payoh and Tan Tock Seng Hospitals to provide more beds to meet the needs of the increasing population in Ang Mo Kio, Yishun and Bishan New Towns.

    The Ministry is currently looking into the possibility of establishing community hospitals in some of the major housing estates. Plans for one community hospital to be built as a pilot project are expected to be finalized before the end of this year.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, may I know from the Minister of State when the redevelopment of Toa Payoh and Tan Tock Seng Hospitals will be carried out?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Plans for the redevelopment of these two hospitals are expected to be completed within the next 18 months.

PRICE OF SUGAR


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) if he is aware that the retail and industry price of sugar of $1.15 per kilogram is higher than the prevailing world prices of refined sugar and whether this is due to Government's protection of the Sugar Industry of Singapore Limited; and (b) whether the Government intends to liberalize the import of sugar and, if not, why not.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the prevailing world price of sugar is low, as there has been excess production in major exporting countries in the last three years. We do not expect the present glut to last long. Some producers have already reduced the acreage for planting of beet and cane sugar.

    Like most commodity prices, sugar prices fluctuate widely. The price of imported white sugar has varied from a high of $2,017 per metric ton in 1974 to the current low of $481. As sugar is an essential commodity, it is desirable to protect our consumers against these drastic swings. Hence, to safeguard the

Column: 1354

interest of consumers, the Sugar Industry of Singapore (SIS) has, since 1973, had long-term supply contracts with Australia covering about two-thirds of its requirements. These long-term contracts have enabled consumers to enjoy a stable price of sugar over a long period. On average, over the last decade, consumers in Singapore have paid slightly less than the world prices for SIS's sugar. The arrangement also assures Singapore of a ready supply of sugar during a crisis, as SIS is responsible to the Government to keep adequate stocks of raw and refined sugar.

    The current retail price of $1.15 per kilogram for refined sugar in Singapore is comparable to prices in other ASEAN countries, and is lower than in most net sugar importing countries elsewhere. For example, Hong Kong relies entirely on the spot market for its sugar, yet their prices are higher than ours.

    Nevertheless, my Ministry is carefully monitoring the situation and will review and revise the existing policy when it no longer serves the interest of Singaporeans.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I ask Question No. 7, may I say that I am a member of the PUB Board, and this question is asked in the interest of the public. Sir, Question No. 7.

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Alternative fuel for electricity generation)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, as the possibility of a disruption in oil supplies in the future cannot be ruled out despite the current depressed world oil prices, whether the Public Utilities Board has taken the necessary steps to diversify its energy resources for electricity generation.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, although oil prices have come off their peak, the Public Utilities Board has not relaxed its efforts to search for an alternative fuel for electricity generation. The various alternatives considered include nuclear energy, coal and natural gas.

Column: 1355



    Nuclear power plants are low in fuel costs but high in capital costs. Although nuclear energy is "clean" - nuclear plants do not emit products of combustion as do fossil fuel-burning plants - it presents many other problems. Firstly, nuclear reactors are only economical above a certain minimum size. Singapore is unlikely to consume this much electricity until after the year 2000. Then there are problems of safety and disposal of nuclear waste, which are particularly hazardous in densely populated Singapore.

    In 1982, we conducted a study to look into the feasibility of building a coal-fi red power station on Pulau Tekong. Coal would be cheaper than oil. However, unlike oil and natural gas, coal is very difficult to handle and use. A large area is required for storage of coal and disposal of ash. Moreover, because of our size and dense population, the attendant environmental pollution will be undesirable. The PUB has not yet decided to proceed with the project.

    Other alternatives such as natural gas are being looked into. As stated in the MTI Addendum to the President's Address, the PUB is negotiating with Petronas on the supply of natural gas from Malaysia. It is willing to buy natural gas on fair commercial terms, and will negotiate for a long term contract to ensure security of supply at prices competitive with fuel oil. Discussions are continuing, and are progressing satisfactorily.

    Head L -

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have three amendments*

Column: 1356

under this Head. May I have your permission to move the first and third amendments, and have your permission to speak for 20 minutes since there are two amendments involved and the subjects are interrelated.

     The Chairman: It is all right.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head L be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead LA-01 Object Group 1100 of the Main Estimates.*

    In moving this amendment, I wish to take this opportunity to comment on the streaming policy of the Education Ministry, particularly in regard to the manner in which it is implemented.

    The Hon. Minister for Education, on 7th March in this House, in his statement pointed out the fact that streaming is not new. Let me quote what he said:

    'Putting children into various streams, so that they can learn at their own pace, simply recognizes the fact that those who are clever can learn fast, and those who are not so clever can also learn but at a slower pace. Streaming is not a new concept. It existed from the time when all of us were school children. The cleverest pupils were put into the A class, those who were not-so-clever into the B or the C class, right down to the G and H classes.'

    While there is no denying the validity of his statement, there is also no denying that there has never been so much criticism and objection to the way streaming has been implemented at present. Why is this so?

    The reasons are plain and simple. Streaming as implemented at present does more than just providing students with varying abilities to learn at their own pace. It also unfortunately deprives certain groups, such as the Monolingual at the primary level, from having an opportunity to sit for the PSLE, and the majority of N4 students from proceeding to N5 where they can sit for the 'O' level examination. Now this, to put it in a nutshell, is the underlying cause of so much frustration and dissatisfaction with the system.

Column: 1357



    To every primary school child and his parents, the opportunity to sit for the PSLE is very important, as it provides the child with a passport to further education in a secondary school. He may pass or fail, and he knows that there can be no guarantee of success. But what he should have, after completing his primary education, whether he takes six years or eight years, is an opportunity to sit for the PSLE. Is he asking too much or are his parents asking too much for just an opportunity to sit for the PSLE? The answer must surely be in the negative.

    Today, the opportunity for a primary school child to sit for the PSLE after completion of his primary education is dependent on which stream he is placed in after the Primary 3 examination. Is it any wonder that parents with children in Primary 1, 2, and 3 are losing sleep and getting neurotic over the possibility that their children might end up in the Monolingual stream? This is why we hear that even Primary 1 children are receiving private tuition. How much more absurd can the situation become?

    The secondary school student who happens to be placed in the Normal stream faces the uncertainty of whether he will have a chance to sit for the 'O' level, because at N4 level, he must sit for a national examination set by the Cambridge Syndicate. And even though he passed, if he fails to obtain an aggregate of 9 points for 3 subjects, inclusive of English which must be at least 3 points, he will not be allowed to proceed to N5.

    Why should such an obstacle now be placed in his path? Why should such a high standard be set? Is it not true that in the past a student at Secondary 3, after having passed the school examination which, by the way, is not usually as difficult as a national examination set by Cambridge, could proceed to Secondary 4 and sit for the GCE 'O' level? Is it not true that the grading for the CSE examination set by Cambridge for N4 students ranges from 1-6 points, and those who scored 1-5 points for any subject are considered to have passed? In other words, those who have scored 5 points also passed, except

Column: 1358

that it is a weak pass. So a student with 5 points for English should be considered to have passed his English paper, and if he also obtains 5 points in two other subjects, he should be considered to have passed. If this is so, then should not the aggregate for the best three subjects, inclusive of English, be 15 points as the criterion for entry to N5?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have mentioned two obnoxious features of the present streaming system. These, to me and to many others, make the present streaming system so unacceptable.

    Many parents and teachers can perhaps accept streaming if, at the end of it, children are not deprived of an opportunity to sit for our two very important national examinations, namely, the PSLE and the 'O' level. True, not all children are born equally endowed, but are not all Singaporean children entitled to an equal opportunity in education? If streaming is to let every child learn at his own pace, then streaming should let every child have an equal opportunity to sit for the PSLE and the 'O' level. I am painfully aware that even with the equal opportunity accorded, not every child is going to pass the PSLE or the 'O' level. There are those who will not be able to go beyond their primary education and those who will not be able to get 3 or more 'O' level passes. Our examination system will determine who passes and at what level.

    Let me now propose to the Hon. Minister the following modifications to the present streaming policy and procedures. With reference to primary schools:

    (a) the existing Monolingual stream should be abolished. Make special arrangements for the educationally subnormal children;

    (b) the present Normal and Extended streams in the primary level be renamed Express and Normal streams. The Express stream should take three years and the Normal stream four years before PSLE;

    (c) Primary 6 children in the Express stream who fail at the PSLE should be allowed to repeat Primary 6 in the Normal stream; and

Column: 1359



    (d) Primary 6 children in the Normal stream who fail at the PSLE should be allowed to repeat one more year.

    With reference to secondary schools:

    (a) Children, after having sat for the PSLE and passed, should be channelled to the present Secondary Express stream or Normal stream;

    (b) Children, after having sat for the PSLE but failed after repeated sittings for the PSLE, should be channelled to the VITB after a one-year proficiency course in English and Mathematics; and

    (c) The stipulation, that those who sit for N4 must satisfy present criteria before they are allowed to proceed to N5, should be removed. Instead, those who pass in three subjects inclusive of English, ie, those with 5 points and below for each subject, should be allowed to proceed to N5.

    I am aware, Mr Speaker, Sir, that it is very easy to offer ideas on how the education system should be restructured, but more often than not, the ideas are difficult to implement. So I met some 50-odd principals and teachers from junior colleges, secondary and primary schools and discussed with them whether the proposals I have just mentioned are educationally sound and can be implemented effectively in schools, taking into account that the Education Ministry is firmly adopting streaming as a policy. The general response is an overwhelming yes.

    Finally, I would like to draw the attention of the House to another problematic aspect of streaming. Many teachers have questioned the wisdom of using such negative labels such as Extended and Monolingual. Labels of this nature have a deleterious effect on the morale of less able students. Now, it has been found that teachers tend to have poor expectation of pupils who have been labelled as slow learners. It has been shown to be psychological truth that pupils tend to perform according to expectation. Treat them as if they are inferior and they will usually turn out to be inferior, This is referred to as the self-fulfilling prophecy syndrome.

Column: 1360



    Pupils who have been labelled as Monolingual or Extended also tend to feel the stigma of being classified as inferior beings. In a recent study, it has been shown that the behaviour in these classes is particularly bad and teachers tend to dread dealing with these pupils. Is this bad behaviour symptomatic and is this the resentment pupils in these classes must feel? Is this not a self-imposed problem? It will be noted that we do not have this problem before these labels began to be used.

    I would like to ask whether there is really a necessity to use such labels. That is why I have proposed that in the upper Primary, the Monolingual stream be abolished and the present Normal and Extended streams be renamed Express and Normal streams. I do not expect the Education Minister to react immediately to my proposals, but I will commend him to take my proposals into consideration when he reviews the present education policy on streaming.

The Member for Moulmein is a professional educationist, He is the President of the Singapore Teachers' Union, and I believe he is a knowledgeable man in respect of matters pertaining to education. If so, in having this streaming at Primary 6, does it not affect this group of pupils who may be in the slow developer category?

    The other aspect is this. Does the Member for Moulmein agree that many of our educational problems are, in fact, in the school itself? And one of the teaching problems is the high enrolment in our classrooms. I believe the average class has about 40 pupils and I know of classes having as many as 46 pupils in a class. Does he then not recognize that many of the major educational problems are, in fact, in the schools?
